entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.text: 2016-01-13 The canonpath function in the File::Spec module (from the PathTools distribution) was not properly preserving the taint attribute of data. This was fixed in PathTools 3.62, released on Monday 11th January. ActivePerl has also been updated with this and another Windows-specific security fix. Strawberry Perl was also updated.
entries.title: CVE on File::Spec

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.text: David's monthly round-up of new modules on CPAN. His module of the month was Protocol::ACME.
entries.title: What's new on CPAN - December 2015

entries.author: sawyer_x
entries.text: Sawyer fills us in on recent releases of Dancer2.
entries.title: New Dancer2 releases

entries.author: kenichi_ishigaki
entries.text: Ishigaki-san has a release candidate out for the next stable release of DBD::SQLite, which if all goes to plan should happen in the middle of next month.
entries.title: Next stable DBD::SQLite will be released in mid February

entries.author: sawyer_x
entries.text: Updates from Tony Cook and Dave Mitchell on their grant work; some new bugs were reported, some existing bugs got fixed, and a bunch of stuff was discussed.
entries.title: P5P summary: January 4th-10th

entries.text: Gizmo presents something he knocked up with RapidApp, to making information about some gaming conferences available.
entries.title: Gaming Con event filtering and RapidApp

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: Some thoughts on how we can make CPAN distributions more welcoming to potential contributors.
entries.title: Making your CPAN dist contribution-friendly

entries.author: mike_friedman
entries.text: An introduction to subroutine signatures in Perl 6.
entries.title: Exploring Perl 6: Signatures, Part 1

entries.author: zoffix_znet
entries.text: Prompted by all the discussion and snarky comments, Zoffix has started a repository where he's trying to bring together a high-level description of "the Perl 6 experience": how to present and talk about 6.
entries.title: The Perl 6 User Experience

entries.author: mike_friedman
entries.text: Mike continues his exploration of Perl 6, by looking at some meta operators.
entries.title: Exploring Perl 6: Meta Operators

entries.author: curtis_ovid_poe
entries.text: This tweet from Ovid kicked off a number of discussons, blog posts, tweet storms, and an eye roll from Aristotle.
entries.title: Get off my lawn

entries.author: zoffix_znet
entries.text: Zoffix's passionate support for Perl 6, in response to the brouhaha. He's having fun with Perl 6, and thinks many other people will too.
entries.title: Why in The World Would Anyone Use Perl 6?

entries.author: joel_berger
entries.text: Joel's allegory about the naming of Perl 6.
entries.title: On the Semantic Naming of Things

entries.author: sue_spence
entries.text: Sue's calm thoughts on the whole naming issue: both Perl 5 and Perl 6 came from Larry, so he gets to decide on the name, regardless of what any of the rest of us might think.
entries.title: Perl: Names, Logos and Who Gets To Decide

entries.text: A script from Hasan for stripping attachments from email. He's hoping to get comments and suggestions for improving his code.
entries.title: How to Strip Attachments from Email

entries.author: sinan_unur
entries.text: Not a Perl article, but it involves Sinan and brian, so I feel honour-bound to include it. Sinan made some code run a lot quicker.
entries.title: An Excellent Optimization Story

entries.text: Some advice on how to get resolutions and goals for new year to stick. Apparently this is the time when most people fall off the wagon, so it seemed the right time for this article.
entries.title: Making Change Stick

header:
Plenty of back-and-forth between the Perl 5 and Perl 6 camps this week.
I think this is healthy, as long as it doesn't go on too long.
For one, it's a sign of people who care about their communities
and programming languages.
We've also got David Farrell's review of new CPAN modules from December.
subject: Seconds out ...
